fava.datatypes
Class StateMachine<STATE,INPUT>

java.lang.Object
  fava.datatypes.StateMachine<STATE,INPUT>
Type Parameters:
STATE - The datatype representing the state of the StateMachine
INPUT - the type of input that this StateMachine operates on
public abstract class StateMachine<STATE,INPUT>
extends java.lang.Object

The StateMachine class models a simple state machine which alters its state based on provided input.

Author:
Nathaniel Sherry

Constructor Summary
StateMachine(STATE initial)
           
 
Method Summary
 STATE getState()
          Gets the current state value
protected abstract  STATE processInput(INPUT input, STATE state)
          This method should be implemented by implementations of StateMachine.
 void resetState()
          Resets the state of the StateMachine by holding a reference to the state that was given to the StateMachine when it was initialised, or when it was last reset by calling StateMachine#resetState(STATE s)

If the state data structure being used by an implementation is itself stateful, and is modified by new input, rather than being replaced the resetState method should be overridden to set the state to a fresh instance of the state data structure by creating the new instance, initialising it, and calling StateMachine#resetState(STATE s)
protected  void resetState(STATE s)
          This method is used to set the state of the StateMachine, but also to set the initial state of the machine.
 void setState(STATE s)
          Sets the current state of the StateMachine
 STATE speculate(INPUT i)
          This method returns what the state would be if the StateMachine were to be transitioned on this input

Note: if a StateMachine updates a data structure rather than returning a new state value, a call to speculate will have the same effect as a call to StateMachine#transition(INPUT i))
 STATE speculate(INPUT[] is)
          This method returns what the state would be if the StateMachine were to be transitioned on this list of inputs sequentially

Note: if a StateMachine updates a data structure rather than returning a new state value, a call to speculate will have the same effect as a call to StateMachine#transition(INPUT i)
 STATE speculate(INPUT i, STATE starting)
          This method returns what the state would be if the StateMachine were to be transitioned on this list of inputs sequentially from a given starting input

Note: if a StateMachine updates a data structure rather than returning a new state value, a call to speculate will alter the provided starting state.
 STATE speculate(java.util.List<INPUT> is)
          This method returns what the state would be if the StateMachine were to be transitioned on this list of inputs sequentially

Note: if a StateMachine updates a data structure rather than returning a new state value, a call to speculate will have the same effect as a call to StateMachine#transition(INPUT i)
 STATE transition(INPUT i)

Constructor Detail

StateMachine

public StateMachine(STATE initial)
Method Detail

processInput

protected abstract STATE processInput(INPUT input,
                                      STATE state)
This method should be implemented by implementations of StateMachine. This is where specific state machines define their behaviour on input.

Parameters:
input - the input to the state machine
state - the current state
Returns:
the new state of the StateMachine

getState

public STATE getState()
Gets the current state value

Returns:
current state of the StateMachine

setState

public void setState(STATE s)
Sets the current state of the StateMachine

Parameters:
s - the new state of the StateMachine

resetState

public void resetState()
Resets the state of the StateMachine by holding a reference to the state that was given to the StateMachine when it was initialised, or when it was last reset by calling StateMachine#resetState(STATE s)

If the state data structure being used by an implementation is itself stateful, and is modified by new input, rather than being replaced the resetState method should be overridden to set the state to a fresh instance of the state data structure by creating the new instance, initialising it, and calling StateMachine#resetState(STATE s)

resetState

protected void resetState(STATE s)
This method is used to set the state of the StateMachine, but also to set the initial state of the machine. If resetState() is called after a call to this method, the StateMachine's state will reset to the value provided to this method, rather than a previous value provided at initialisation.

Subclasses of StateMachine overridding the resetState() method should call this method once they have initialsed the desired state.

Parameters:
s - the new value and default/initial value of this StateMachine

transition

public STATE transition(INPUT i)
This method transitions the StateMachine from the current state to a new state based on the input i

Parameters:
i - the input to the StateMachine
Returns:
the new state of the StateMachine

transition

public STATE transition(java.util.List<INPUT> is)
This method accepts a list of inputs to the StateMachine, and transitions the StateMachine based on the input one item at a time

Parameters:
is - the list of input for the StateMachine
Returns:
the final state after transitioning for all input

transition

public STATE transition(INPUT[] is)
This method accepts an array of inputs to the StateMachine, and transitions the StateMachine based on the input one item at a time

Parameters:
is - the array of input for the StateMachine
Returns:
the final state after transitioning for all input

speculate

public STATE speculate(INPUT i)
This method returns what the state would be if the StateMachine were to be transitioned on this input

Note: if a StateMachine updates a data structure rather than returning a new state value, a call to speculate will have the same effect as a call to StateMachine#transition(INPUT i))

Parameters:
i - the input to the StateMachine
Returns:
the state of the StateMachine, were it to be given this input

speculate

public STATE speculate(INPUT i,
                       STATE starting)
This method returns what the state would be if the StateMachine were to be transitioned on this list of inputs sequentially from a given starting input

Note: if a StateMachine updates a data structure rather than returning a new state value, a call to speculate will alter the provided starting state.

Parameters:
i - the input to the StateMachine
starting - the prospective initial state of the StateMachine
Returns:
the state of the StateMachine, were it to be given this input

speculate

public STATE speculate(java.util.List<INPUT> is)
This method returns what the state would be if the StateMachine were to be transitioned on this list of inputs sequentially

Note: if a StateMachine updates a data structure rather than returning a new state value, a call to speculate will have the same effect as a call to StateMachine#transition(INPUT i)

Parameters:
is - the inputs to the StateMachine
Returns:
the state of the StateMachine, were it to be given this input

speculate

public STATE speculate(INPUT[] is)
This method returns what the state would be if the StateMachine were to be transitioned on this list of inputs sequentially

Note: if a StateMachine updates a data structure rather than returning a new state value, a call to speculate will have the same effect as a call to StateMachine#transition(INPUT i)

Parameters:
is - the inputs to the StateMachine
Returns:
the state of the StateMachine, were it to be given this input
